page.title: 03BUILDINGS ON MARK MOOR
page.content: Farmhouses twelve scattered over the area. Most dating from the late 18th century, built of stone, said to be from the Polden hills, now faced with red brick for durability. Farm facilities, all have dutch barns for storage of hay & straw, milking parlours with concrete holding yards & large covered yards known as cubicles for housing milking cows or store cattle in the winter. Outlying buildings each farm has either a portable milking ball or a permanent milking parlour in the area of the pastures. Dwellings, a sprinkling of old stone cottages mostly modernised & used as private houses, no tied cottages remain. In the N.E. corner is an area of infilling where ten new bungalows are interspersed with old houses.
